abstract.text: Detect nearby accessories and facilitate their setup.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use the AccessorySetupKit framework to simplify discovery and configuration of Bluetooth or Wi-Fi accessories. This allows the person using your app to use these devices without granting overly-broad Bluetooth or Wi-Fi access.
To discover accessories and present them in your app:
Declare that your app uses AccessorySetupKit in its information property list.
In your app, create and activate an instance of
Provide information about your supported accessories to display a picker. This lets the person using your app discover and select nearby accessories to configure.
When the picker sends an accessory added event, use information about the selected device to create a Bluetooth or Wi-Fi connection.
To prepare your app to discover accessories, add the
key to its information property list.
Set its value to an array of strings that contains one or more of the following values:
Add this value if your app discovers accessories using Bluetooth or Bluetooth Low Energy.
Add this value if your app discovers accessories by finding Wi-Fi SSIDs that the accessories publish.
If you add
to the list of supported protocols, you also need to add the following keys and values to your app’s information property list:
An array of strings that represent the Bluetooth company identifiers for accessories your app configures.
An array of strings that represent the Bluetooth device names for accessories your app configures.
An array of strings that represent the hexadecimal values of Bluetooth services for accessories your app configures.

If your app tries to discover Bluetooth accessories during setup without supplying these keys and values, or uses identifiers, names, or services that it doesn’t include in its information property list, the app crashes. This only affects use of AccessorySetupKit discovery and selection; you can use other services and properties on the accessory after the person using the app selects it.
The
is how your app uses the AccessorySetupKit framework. In your app, you create an instance of
and activate it to receive callbacks with events as the session processes events. The
method takes a
and an event-handling block or closure. The callbacks occur on the provided queue, which defaults to
The event handler receives a single parameter of type
, which has an
that you use to determine what to do with each callback. For example, shortly after activating the session, your callback receives the
event. The following listing comments on the meaning of these events and how you may want to handle them.

code: // Handle addition of an accessory by person using the app.
// Handle removal or change of previously-added
// The session is now invalid and you can't use it further.
// Update state for picker appearing, if necessary.
// Update state for picker disappearing, if necessary.
// Handle unknown event type, if appropriate.
// Reserve this space for yet-to-be-defined event types.

inlineContent.text: When the session activates, its

array contains any accessories previously authorized for the app, which you can inspect. To discover new devices, your app needs to show an accessory picker. The person using the app uses this picker to choose the accessory to configure.
If someone renames a previously-discovered Wi-Fi accessory, it becomes discoverable again by the picker.
Create instances of
that describe the items in the session that your app can configure. Collect these items in an array and pass them to the session for the operating system to present a picker:

code: descriptor.bluetoothServiceUUID = CBUUID(string: MY_ACCESSORY_UUID_STRING) // If using Wi-Fi, set descriptor.ssid instead.
guard let productImage = UIImage(named: MY_ACCESSORY_IMAGE_NAME) else { return }
// Create additional picker items if you support multiple accessories
// with different Wi-Fi SSIDs or Bluetooth service UUIDs.
// If the picker finished by selecting an item, the event
// handler receives it as an event of type `.accessoryAdded`.

inlineContent.text: Each display item’s
, a property of type
, needs to have a
or
, and at least one of the following accessory identifiers:
A
and
set to the same length.
A
and
set to the same length.
Either
or
, which needs to have a non-zero length. Only supply one of these; the app crashes if you supply both.
For Bluetooth accessories, the accessory identifiers you use in display items need to match the values you supply in the app’s information property list.
Along with filtering matched accessories to show in the picker, the display item and its descriptor allow you to control certain behaviors of the picker interaction. You can limit the

of the descriptor to only match accessories in the immediate physical proximity of the device running the app. To specify behaviors like allowing renaming of the accessory during setup, or confirming accessory authorization before showing the setup view, set the display item’s

When the picker appears, the person using the app sees a view of all nearby accessories that match the identifiers you provide. When multiple devices match a given identifier, the picker shows a separate item for each unique device. This allows the person to select a single device with the picker.

content.text: Use the picker when migrating to AccessorySetupKit

inlineContent.text: You can also perform a one-time migration of previously-configured accessories, which adds them to the AccessorySetupKit framework’s list of known accessories. To do this, create instances of
and include them in the array of items you send to
For items you want to migrate, set one or both of the following:
A
, which must be a full SSID and not a prefix.
A
, which corresponds to the
property of the
type.
Don’t initialize a
before migration is complete. If you do, your callback handler receives an error and the picker fails to appear.

content.text: Connect and configure the selected device

inlineContent.text: When the person picks an accessory, the picker sends an event of type
, followed by an

event when they dismiss the picker. If your app presents its own UI to configure the accessory, wait for the picker to dismiss, then use the accessory from the first event. You can handle this scenario by rewriting your event handler closure from before as follows, storing the accessory on the first event and retrieving it on the second.

code: guard let accessory = self.pickedAccessory else { return }

inlineContent.text: The event’s
property contains details of the selected device, like its
and an
for Bluetooth devices or
for Wi-Fi. Use this information to connect to the accessory — using
for Bluetooth or
for Wi-Fi — and begin your device-specific setup process.

code: // Use Core Bluetooth to communicate with and configure the accessory.
// Create a `NEHotspotConfiguration` with this SSID to configure.

inlineContent.text: Because the app discovered the device with AccessorySetupKit, connecting to the device won’t invoke the TCC or other alerts that the system normally shows when using these system frameworks.

authorizing-a-bluetooth-accessory-PageIm.alt: An illustration of a die over a background patterned with the Bluetooth logo.

abstract.text: Enable privacy-preserving discovery and configuration of accessories.
The accessory’s unique Bluetooth identifier, if any.
The accessory’s name, suitable for displaying to someone using your app.
The accessory’s Wi-Fi SSID, if any.
Properties of an event encountered during accessory discovery.
The accessory involved in the event, if any.
The type of event, such as accessory addition or removal, or picker presentation or removal.
The session added an accessory.
The discovery session activated.
The discovery session picker dismissed.
A class to coordinate accessory discovery.
An array of previously-selected accessories for this application.
Activate the session and start delivering events to an event handler.
Present a picker that shows discovered accessories matching an array of display items.
Descriptive traits used to discover accessories.
The accessory’s 16-bit Bluetooth Company Identifier.
A byte buffer that matches the accessory’s Bluetooth manufacturer data.
The accessory’s Bluetooth manufacturer data mask.
The accessory’s over-the-air Bluetooth name substring.
A property that tells the session to discover accessories within a specific Bluetooth range.
A byte buffer that matches the accessory’s Bluetooth service data.
The accessory’s Bluetooth service data mask.
The accessory’s Bluetooth service UUID.
The SSID of the accessory’s Wi-Fi network.
The prefix string of SSID of the accessory’s Wi-Fi network.
A previously-discovered accessory as presented by the discovery picker, for use when migrating it to AccessorySetupKit.
The Wi-Fi hotspot SSID of the accessory to migrate.
The Bluetooth identifier of the accessory to migrate.
An accessory as presented by the discovery picker.
A descriptor that the picker uses to determine which discovered accessories to display.
Custom setup options for the accessory.
Discover, select, and set up a specific Bluetooth accessory without requesting permission to use Bluetooth.

doc://com.apple.AccessorySetupKit/docume.title: Authorizing a Bluetooth accessory to share a dice roll

abstract.text: Communicate with Bluetooth low energy and BR/EDR (“Classic”) Devices.
An object that scans for, discovers, connects to, and manages peripherals.
An object that represents a remote device.
The UUID associated with the peer.
An object that manages the execution of tasks serially or concurrently on your app’s main thread or on a background thread.
The dispatch queue associated with the main thread of the current process.
Customize and extend core networking features.
